segment.source: A Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app can run on any Windows-based device, from your phone to your tablet or PC.
segment.target: A Universal Windows Platform (UWP) app can run on any Windows-based device, from your phone to your tablet or PC.

segment.source: Designing an app that looks good on such a wide variety of devices can be a big challenge.
segment.target: Designing an app that looks good on such a wide variety of devices can be a big challenge.

segment.source: So how do you go about designing an app that provides a great UX on devices with dramatically different screen sizes and input methods?
segment.target: So how do you go about designing an app that provides a great UX on devices with dramatically different screen sizes and input methods?

segment.source: Fortunately, the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) provides a set of built-in features and universal building blocks that help you do just that.
segment.target: Fortunately, the Universal Windows Platform (UWP) provides a set of built-in features and universal building blocks that help you do just that.

segment.source: This articles describes the UI features and benefits of UWP apps and provides some high-level design guidance for creating your first UWP app.
segment.target: This articles describes the UI features and benefits of UWP apps and provides some high-level design guidance for creating your first UWP app.

segment.source: Let's start by taking a look at some of the features that you get when you create a UWP app.

segment.source: Effective pixels and scaling
segment.target: Effective pixels and scaling

segment.source: UWP apps automatically adjust the size of controls, fonts, and other UI elements so that they are legible on all devices.
segment.target: UWP apps automatically adjust the size of controls, fonts, and other UI elements so that they are legible on all devices.

segment.source: When your app runs on a device, the system uses an algorithm to normalize the way UI elements display on the screen.
segment.target: When your app runs on a device, the system uses an algorithm to normalize the way UI elements display on the screen.

segment.source: This scaling algorithm takes into account viewing distance and screen density (pixels per inch) to optimize for perceived size (rather than physical size).
segment.target: This scaling algorithm takes into account viewing distance and screen density (pixels per inch) to optimize for perceived size (rather than physical size).

segment.source: The scaling algorithm ensures that a 24 px font on Surface Hub 10 feet away is just as legible to the user as a 24 px font on 5' phone that's a few inches away.
segment.target: The scaling algorithm ensures that a 24 px font on Surface Hub 10 feet away is just as legible to the user as a 24 px font on 5' phone that's a few inches away.

segment.source: viewing distances for different devices
segment.target: viewing distances for different devices

segment.source: Because of how the scaling system works, when you design your UWP app, you're designing in effective pixels, not actual physical pixels.
segment.target: Because of how the scaling system works, when you design your UWP app, you're designing in effective pixels, not actual physical pixels.

segment.source: So, how does that impact the way you design your app?
segment.target: So, how does that impact the way you design your app?

segment.source: You can ignore the pixel density and the actual screen resolution when designing.
segment.target: You can ignore the pixel density and the actual screen resolution when designing.

segment.source: Instead, design for the effective resolution (the resolution in effective pixels) for a size class (we define size classes later in this article).
segment.target: Instead, design for the effective resolution (the resolution in effective pixels) for a size class (we define size classes later in this article).

segment.source: When the system scales your UI, it does so by multiples of 4.
segment.target: When the system scales your UI, it does so by multiples of 4.

segment.source: To ensure a crisp appearance, snap your designs to the 4x4 pixel grid: make margins, sizes and positions of UI elements, and the position (but not the size—text can be any size) of text a multiple of 4 effective pixels.
segment.target: To ensure a crisp appearance, snap your designs to the 4x4 pixel grid: make margins, sizes and positions of UI elements, and the position (but not the size—text can be any size) of text a multiple of 4 effective pixels.

segment.source: Universal input and smart interactions
segment.target: Universal input and smart interactions

segment.source: Another built-in capability of the UWP is universal input enabled via smart interactions.
segment.target: Another built-in capability of the UWP is universal input enabled via smart interactions.

segment.source: Although you can design your apps for specific input modes and devices, you aren’t required to.
segment.target: Although you can design your apps for specific input modes and devices, you aren’t required to.

segment.source: That’s because Universal Windows apps by default rely on smart interactions.
segment.target: That’s because Universal Windows apps by default rely on smart interactions.

segment.source: That means you can design around a click interaction without having to know or define whether the click comes from an actual mouse click or the tap of a finger.
segment.target: That means you can design around a click interaction without having to know or define whether the click comes from an actual mouse click or the tap of a finger.

segment.source: Universal controls and styles
segment.target: Universal controls and styles

segment.source: The UWP also provides some useful building blocks that make it easier to design apps for multiple device families.
segment.target: The UWP also provides some useful building blocks that make it easier to design apps for multiple device families.

segment.source: Universal controls
segment.target: Universal controls

segment.source: The UWP provides a set of universal controls that are guaranteed to work well on all Windows-powered devices.
segment.target: The UWP provides a set of universal controls that are guaranteed to work well on all Windows-powered devices.

segment.source: This set of universal controls includes everything from common form controls like radio button and text box to sophisticated controls like grid view and list view that can generate lists of items from a stream of data and a template.
segment.target: This set of universal controls includes everything from common form controls like radio button and text box to sophisticated controls like grid view and list view that can generate lists of items from a stream of data and a template.

segment.source: These controls are input-aware and deploy with the proper set of input affordances, event states, and overall functionality for each device family.
segment.target: These controls are input-aware and deploy with the proper set of input affordances, event states, and overall functionality for each device family.

segment.source: For a complete list of these controls and the patterns you can make from them, see the Controls and patterns section.
segment.target: For a complete list of these controls and the patterns you can make from them, see the Controls and patterns section.

segment.source: Now that we've described the building blocks of UWP apps, let's take a look at how to put them together to create a UI.
segment.target: Now that we've described the building blocks of UWP apps, let's take a look at how to put them together to create a UI.

segment.source: The anatomy of a typical UWP app
segment.target: The anatomy of a typical UWP app

segment.source: A modern user interface is a complex thing, made up of text, shapes, colors, and animations which are ultimately made up out of individual pixels of the screen of the device you're using.
segment.target: A modern user interface is a complex thing, made up of text, shapes, colors, and animations which are ultimately made up out of individual pixels of the screen of the device you're using.

segment.source: When you start designing a user interface, the sheer number of choices can be overwhelming.
segment.target: When you start designing a user interface, the sheer number of choices can be overwhelming.

segment.source: To make things simpler, let's define the anatomy of an app from a design perspective.
segment.target: To make things simpler, let's define the anatomy of an app from a design perspective.

segment.source: Let's say that an app is made up of screens and pages.
segment.target: Let's say that an app is made up of screens and pages.

segment.source: Each page has a user interface, made up of three types of UI elements: navigation, commanding, and content elements.
segment.target: Each page has a user interface, made up of three types of UI elements: navigation, commanding, and content elements.

segment.source: Navigation elements
segment.target: Navigation elements

segment.source: Navigation elements help users choose the content they want to display.
segment.target: Navigation elements help users choose the content they want to display.

segment.source: Examples of navigation elements include tabs and pivots, hyperlinks, and nav panes.
segment.target: Examples of navigation elements include tabs and pivots, hyperlinks, and nav panes.

segment.source: Navigation elements are covered in detail in the Navigation design basics article.
segment.target: Navigation elements are covered in detail in the Navigation design basics article.

segment.source: Command elements
segment.target: Command elements

segment.source: Command elements initiate actions, such as manipulating, saving, or sharing content.
segment.target: Command elements initiate actions, such as manipulating, saving, or sharing content.

segment.source: Examples of command elements include button and the command bar.
segment.target: Examples of command elements include button and the command bar.

segment.source: Command elements can also include keyboard shortcuts that aren't actually visible on the screen.
segment.target: Command elements can also include keyboard shortcuts that aren't actually visible on the screen.

segment.source: Command elements are covered in detail in the Command design basics article.
segment.target: Command elements are covered in detail in the Command design basics article.

segment.source: Content elements
segment.target: Content elements

segment.source: Content elements display the app's content.
segment.target: Content elements display the app's content.

segment.source: For a painting app, the content might be a drawing; for a news app, the content might be a news article.
segment.target: For a painting app, the content might be a drawing; for a news app, the content might be a news article.

segment.source: Content elements are covered in detail in the Content design basics article.
segment.target: Content elements are covered in detail in the Content design basics article.

segment.source: At a minimum, an app has a splash screen and a home page that defines the user interface.
segment.target: At a minimum, an app has a splash screen and a home page that defines the user interface.

segment.source: A typical app will have multiple pages and screens, and navigation, command, and content elements might change from page to page.
segment.target: A typical app will have multiple pages and screens, and navigation, command, and content elements might change from page to page.

segment.source: When deciding on the right UI elements for your app, you might also consider the devices and the screen sizes your app will run on.
segment.target: When deciding on the right UI elements for your app, you might also consider the devices and the screen sizes your app will run on.

segment.source: Tailoring your app for specific devices and screen sizes.
segment.target: Tailoring your app for specific devices and screen sizes.

segment.source: UWP apps use effective pixels to guarantee that your design elements will be legible and usable on all Windows-powered devices.
segment.target: UWP apps use effective pixels to guarantee that your design elements will be legible and usable on all Windows-powered devices.

segment.source: So, why would you ever want to customize your app's UI for a specific device family?
segment.target: So, why would you ever want to customize your app's UI for a specific device family?

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: Before we go any further, Windows doesn't provide a way for your app to detect the specific device your app is running on.
segment.target: Before we go any further, Windows doesn't provide a way for your app to detect the specific device your app is running on.

segment.source: It can tell you the device family (mobile, desktop, etc) the app is running on, the effective resolution, and the amount of screen space available to the app (the size of the app's window).
segment.target: It can tell you the device family (mobile, desktop, etc) the app is running on, the effective resolution, and the amount of screen space available to the app (the size of the app's window).

segment.source: To make the most effective use of space and reduce the need to navigate
segment.target: To make the most effective use of space and reduce the need to navigate

segment.source: If you design an app to look good on a device that has a small screen, such as a phone, the app will be usable on a PC with a much bigger display, but there will probably be some wasted space.
segment.target: If you design an app to look good on a device that has a small screen, such as a phone, the app will be usable on a PC with a much bigger display, but there will probably be some wasted space.

segment.source: You can customize the app to display more content when the screen is above a certain size.
segment.target: You can customize the app to display more content when the screen is above a certain size.

segment.source: For example, a shopping app might display one merchandise category at a time on a phone, but show multiple categories and products simultaneously on a PC or laptop.
segment.target: For example, a shopping app might display one merchandise category at a time on a phone, but show multiple categories and products simultaneously on a PC or laptop.

segment.source: By putting more content on the screen, you reduce the amount of navigation that the user needs to perform.
segment.target: By putting more content on the screen, you reduce the amount of navigation that the user needs to perform.

segment.source: To take advantage of devices' capabilities
segment.target: To take advantage of devices' capabilities

segment.source: Certain devices are more likely to have certain device capabilities.
segment.target: Certain devices are more likely to have certain device capabilities.

segment.source: For example, phones are likely to have a location sensor and a camera, while a PC might not have either.
segment.target: For example, phones are likely to have a location sensor and a camera, while a PC might not have either.

segment.source: Your app can detect which capabilities are available and enable features that use them.
segment.target: Your app can detect which capabilities are available and enable features that use them.

segment.source: To optimize for input
segment.target: To optimize for input

segment.source: The universal control library works with all input types (touch, pen, keyboard, mouse), but you can still optimize for certain input types by re-arranging your UI elements.
segment.target: The universal control library works with all input types (touch, pen, keyboard, mouse), but you can still optimize for certain input types by re-arranging your UI elements.

segment.source: For example, if you place navigation elements at the bottom of the screen, they'll be easier for phone users to access—but most PC users expect to see navigation elements toward the top of the screen.
segment.target: For example, if you place navigation elements at the bottom of the screen, they'll be easier for phone users to access—but most PC users expect to see navigation elements toward the top of the screen.

segment.source: Responsive design techniques
segment.target: Responsive design techniques

segment.source: When you optimize your app's UI for specific screen widths, we say that you're creating a responsive design.
segment.target: When you optimize your app's UI for specific screen widths, we say that you're creating a responsive design.

segment.source: Here are six responsive design techniques you can use to customize your app's UI.
segment.target: Here are six responsive design techniques you can use to customize your app's UI.

segment.source: Reposition
segment.target: Reposition

segment.source: You can alter the location and position of app UI elements to get the most out of each device.
segment.target: You can alter the location and position of app UI elements to get the most out of each device.

segment.source: In this example, the portrait view on phone or phablet necessitates a scrolling UI because only one full frame is visible at a time.
segment.target: In this example, the portrait view on phone or phablet necessitates a scrolling UI because only one full frame is visible at a time.

segment.target: When the app translates to a device that allows two full on-screen frames, whether in portrait or landscape orientation, frame B can occupy a dedicated space.

segment.source: If you're using a grid for positioning, you can stick to the same grid when UI elements are repositioned.
segment.target: If you're using a grid for positioning, you can stick to the same grid when UI elements are repositioned.
